div1.p: Taylor writes that the mother of Clara Louise Maass is receiving a pension. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 12, 1910
div1.opener:
John R. Taylor
Hospital Las Animas
Havana
Cuba.
July 12th 1910
Yellow
Fever
Maj. J. R. Kean
Surgeon
U. S. Army
Washington D. C.
div1.p:
Have been so busy since my return
to Las Animas, that this is the first oportunity I have had
to write.

In connection with the matter I spoke to you about, namely,
that I am under the impression that the Mother of Miss
Maass is receiving a pension, I send you a “clipping” which
will enable you to look the matter up. as to the
exact address of the Maass, I am unable to give you
at this time, as it is several years since I visited
the family. The two addresses I have are 344 Main St
East Orange N. J and 276 Sanford St, East Orange N. J.
I think they are living at the latter address. The Mother's
name is (or was) Mrs Hedwig A Maass and a letter simply
addressed to East Orange N. J, am sure would reach her
if living. Am unable at present to find the data stating
that the pension was given, but am inclined to think
that it was. Kindly return me the clipping when through with it.
In reference to the matter about the fish experiments against the
larvae of mosquitoes, I think you will find the necessary information
which you ask, in the “Sanidad and Benefiremia”, the official
bulletin of the Sanitary Department. It is in Volume III, March, 1910
Number 3, page 226. as Dr Guiteras informs me that you receive this
bulletin, I will not need to go into details.

Later, if you need any information concerning any matter, if
I can be of service, will gladly oblige.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely John R. Taylor Chief of Laboratory
Hospital Las Animas
Havana.
